DOC.HEAD: Police End Prison Disturbance, Free Hostages, Kill 5 Inmates
DOC.TEXT: Police attacked a prison cell block controlled by jailed drug traffickers and rescued 18 hostages held for two days, a Justice Department spokesman said Tuesday. Six traffickers died and five hostages were injured in the bloody rescue operation Monday night. Also Monday in Salgar, a town 167 miles north of Bogota, a group of unidentified men massacred six farmers, the Antioquia state governor's office reported Tuesday. An official communique said authorities still had not determined the motive for the mass killing, and that no arrests had been made. Right-wing death squads have killed scores of other peasants in the same part of Colombia the last year. Later Monday, two police officers were assassinated, apparently by members of Colombia's largest and oldest guerrilla group in La Vega, a town 260 miles south of Bogota, the Cauca state governor's office reported. The assassinations apparently were carried out by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, the communique said. The leftist guerrilla group has increased its activity in recent months. Last Saturday, members of the group ambushed an army patrol and killed 10 soldiers in rural eastern Colombia. The Bogota prison takeover ended Monday when police gained the release of all the hostages, including two children. A Justice Department spokesman told The Associated Press the situation at La Picota jail in southern Bogota had returned to normal. Authorities had been negotiating for two days with the prisoners, who took the hostages after a failed jailbreak Sunday. After subduing guards during visiting hours, the inmates, all jailed on drug trafficking charges, put on guards' uniforms in an attempt to escape, Bogota's El Tiempo newspaper reported Tuesday. Authorities discovered the plan and sealed off the cell block before the prisoners could flee, El Tiempo said, citing prison sources. The paper added that the cornered criminals then took hostages, including civilians who had been visiting their jailed family members. The prisoners initially protested the killing by police of Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, El Tiempo said. The Medellin cartel leader was slain Dec. 15 in a gunfight with police on Colombia's northern coast. As a condition for the hostages' release, the inmates demanded that the administration of President Virgilio Barco end its extradition of drug traffickers, El Tiempo said. The administration has sent 11 drug suspects to the United States since last August when it decreed the policy. The uprising is the second by drug traffickers at a Bogota jail in less than a week. Five prisoners died last Tuesday in a knife battle between rival groups of convicted traffickers at another prison facility in the capital.
